Hey Tim, I was lying in bed this morning and the thought occurred to me that a question in the post in-flight abort test news conference that was not asked but perhaps should have been asked is one involving what constitutes a test of THE "WORST case" scenario and a scenario where THE MOST "natural" or "authentic" configuration of the whole-stack vehicle is implemented. Perhaps you would like to ask about this in some future news conference? My idea of what constitutes THE "worst" case scenario and THE "most natural and authentic configuration" is the following:

Have an in-flight abort test where the 1st stage engines are running at full throttle, at the velocity of the test that actually occurred, but where they are not shut down. What happens is, a small explosive charge set just behind the capsule on the 2nd stage (which is fully loaded with fuel and oxidizer) goes off, triggering a second stage explosion. It's at this point that the capsule attempts to escape the stack. Also, the capsule has been kitted out with all the sensors exactly as in the test that was done but everything else about the capsule remains as it would be in normal mission to the ISS (sans people of course :-). There would be no gutting/stripping of the interior of the capsule. And for good measure they would have a normal 2nd stage with a functioning MVAC engine installed.

What say you about these ideas? What I'm trying to get at here is THE worst case scenario within THE most natural vehicle stack & flight profile to the ISS, with the exception of test instrumentation, (and, of course, without people) that is possible.
Here's a question for you.  Why did the F9 destruct but in the Blue Origin launch abort test the rocket was able to land normally.  I'm guessing the dynamic forces were very different.

Hey Tim! the @Everyday Astronaut: I am very proud of how professional your streams got, I had to watch it recorded because I was having my own live stream coverage in Arabic interactive commentary. I started my channel influenced mainly by you, Scott Manley and Veritasium. When I see you succeed and reach such a level I tend to think I am seeing the future of my channel. I had the honor to host Scott Manley in our live stream of the Annular Solar Eclipse in East Arabia and we got more than 420k views in 2 hours! I never thought I would get this in my wildest dreams. I really hope to host you too and collaborate with you. I gave you a huge shout out in my stream. I know you are busy but I hope we can connect directly to see the many options of collaboration available. And yes, I am Syrian living as a refugee, so my power went off and so did my internet and I had to ask my friend from Egypt to stream the OBS video and my Arabic commentary was sent to him via a phone call. Watch it back I was only a couple of seconds off sync although I was commenting without visual reference other than the timing ... I call that a potato stream hahaha, I am following your lead even in that.
Please, everyone, vote up this comment because Tim really needs to read this to know that he is influencing thousands on the other side of our Pale Blue Globe.
Nooooooooo! :-) Don't worry, great job Tim! We all had fun!

@Tim, nice job with your first launch with the telescope,  First times are always tough, especially with everybody watching,  You and your team seem to have worked through the challenges and got stopped only by the clouds.Regarding the equipment you want, sounds like you are dreaming about a setup like @USLaunchReport (Mike Wagner) has.  If you haven't seen it, go watch their coverage of this launch.  I can't find specs on their equipment; but, they have three telescopes (biggest seems to be about 18") and some other imaging device on a trailer mounted motorized platform all controlled from a studio inside a separate truck,  Very impressive.  Not necessarily a fit for you to do for live shooting; but, impressive none the less.

Can you imagine being a 17 year old kid  who attended the Cape while Apollo 13 was standing on the pad?   My dad took me to the Cape back around 1972 when I was considering becoming a freshman at Florida Tech.  I was looking at the Saturn IV after having taken the standard NASA Apollo tour.  Yes, back in those days, security was of little consequence.  While standing near the VAB I said to my day as a young 17 year old kid:   "Dad, I have a funny feeling about this mission".  My dad said, "why son"? (he always called me son).  I replied, "Because I don't like the number 13, I have a bad feeling about this".   My dad scoffed at me with a little gesture and said "ok, let's go on".  The rest is history.

Thank you for some good coverage of the launch Tim. You guys have a nice setup now for covering launches like this. I have two tips though:


1: With the joystick setup, try adding or increasing the deadzone for neutral position of the joystick. This should help prevent the drift that was happening with the controls by removing any non-zero noise from them when not actually controling the scope mount.


2: look into getting a low reduction "moon filter" for the telescope. They make ones that can fit over the appature of the scope, but one that can fit inline between the camera and the scope would effect the visual quality less and be easier to maintain. A moon filter is just a neutral light lever filter that has no effect on colors. this would make adjusting the cameras brightness a lot easier for you in the future. Just make sure it is not a skyglow filter.

Tim! I'm thinking the part of the rocket that crashed into the ocean was actually the second stage! For some reason, I feel like Falcon 9 was mostly stable as Dragon pulled away from the rocket, which makes me believe that the explosion was potentially triggered automatically instead of breaking apart. It goes against what Elon and others have said about the rocket blowing up anyways due to the aerodynamic forces, but I find that hard to believe from the footage. Either way, the first stage definitely blew up, but I think the second stage kept going, stayed in one piece, and was the same object that splashed into the ocean. It would explain why when it made impact, that there was a huge fireball, because the second stage was full of propellant. Again, I could be wrong, but it was definitely a site to see! Hope more angles and on-board shots come out!
